items.name: Ext.util.DelimitedValue
items.text: This base class contains utility methods for dealing with formats such as CSV (Comma Separated Values) as specified in RFC 4180. The base class implements the mechanics and is governed by these config options: * delimiter * lineBreak * quote These options affect the method-encode and method-decode methods. When *decoding*, however, lineBreak is ignored and instead each line can be separated by any standard line terminator character or character sequence: * ```\u000a``` * ```\u000d``` * ```\u000d\u000a``` Strings which contain the delimiter character are quoted using the quote character, and any internal quote characters are doubled. *Important* While the primary use case is to encode strings, other atomic data types can be encoded as values within a line such as: * Number * Boolean * Date (encoded as an ISO 8601 date string.) * null (encoded as an empty string.) * undefined (encoded as an empty string.) Not that when *decoding*, all data is read as strings. This class does not convert incoming data. To do that, use an Ext.data.reader.Array. See Ext.util.CSV and Ext.util.TSV for pre-configured instances.

items.name: delimiter
items.text: The string used to separate the values in a row. Common values for this config are comma (",") and tab ("\t"). See Ext.util.CSV and Ext.util.TSV for pre-configured instances of these formats.

items.name: lineBreak
items.text: The string used by encode to separate each row. The decode method accepts all forms of line break.

items.name: quote
items.text: The character to use as to quote values that contain the special delimiter or lineBreak characters.

items.name: decode
items.text: Decodes a string of encoded values into an array of rows. Each row is an array of strings. Note that this function does not convert the string values in each column into other data types. To do that, use an Ext.data.reader.Array. For example: Ext.util.CSV.decode('"foo ""bar"", bletch",Normal String,2010-01-01T21:45:32.004Z\u000a3.141592653589793,1,false'); produces the following array of string arrays: [ ['foo "bar", bletch','Normal String', '2010-01-01T21:45:32.004Z'], ['3.141592653589793', '1', 'false'] ]

items.name: delimiter
items.text: The column delimiter to use if the default value of cfg-delimiter is not desired.
An array of rows where each row is an array of Strings.

items.name: encode
items.text:
Converts a two-dimensional array into an encoded string.

For example:

    Ext.util.CSV.encode([
        ['foo "bar", bletch', 'Normal String', new Date()],
        [Math.PI, 1, false]
    ]);

The above produces the following string:

    '"foo ""bar"", bletch",Normal String,2010-01-01T21:45:32.004Z\u000a3.141592653589793,1,false'

items.name: input
items.text: An array of row data arrays.

items.name: delimiter
items.text: The column delimiter to use if the default value of cfg-delimiter is not desired.
A string in which data items are separated by delimiter characters, and rows are separated by lineBreak characters.
